title: How to Wash a Synthetic Insulated Jacket

steps.headline: Run your washing machine through a cycle on empty to clean it.
steps.description: Synthetic insulated jackets are very sensitive to many of the chemicals contained in scented laundry detergents, bleach, and fabric softeners. Therefore, it’s helpful to first run your washing machine through a cycle without anything in it to remove any potentially damaging chemical residue remaining from previous washes. For best results, run it through an empty cycle with hot water.

steps.headline: Zip up all the zippers and turn the jacket inside out.
steps.description: If your jacket has any zippers, zip them up before washing it to help keep it from getting twisted or tangled. Then, turn the jacket inside out to protect the outside fabric from snagging or tearing in the washing machine. In addition, if your jacket has any loose strings, tie these in a bow or knot at the base so that they don’t get tangled or get pulled out of the jacket.

steps.headline: Place the jacket in a front-loading washing machine on the gentle cycle.
steps.description: While top-loading washing machines have agitators that can rip the fabric on your jacket, the gentle cycle on front-loading washing machines doesn’t agitate. Therefore, make sure that you only use a front-loading machine on the gentle cycle to protect the fabric from tears or snags. As an extra precaution, set the washing machine on low heat as well. Keeping the water temperature under 86 °F (30 °C) will help protect the synthetic fabric from damage. Avoid putting anything else in the wash with your jacket to protect the fabric.

steps.headline: Add a detergent for synthetic fabrics and run the gentle wash cycle.
steps.description: Once the jacket is in the washing machine, add a detergent made for synthetic or sporting fabrics to ensure that your jacket isn’t damaged. If the detergent bottle doesn’t specify how much you need to use for a single item, add about 3 ounces (85 g). Then, press the start button to run the jacket through the gentle cycle. Synthetic insulated jackets are sensitive to most detergents, as these tend to contain fragrances and harsh chemicals that can damage the insulation. You can also use fragrance-free Woolite, as it tends to be gentle enough on synthetic insulation.

steps.headline: Mix 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of fragrance-free detergent with water.
steps.description: First, fill your sink or a clean bucket with water. Then, add about 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of fragrance-free detergent and stir it around until the water is sudsy. You may need to add more detergent if the water isn’t getting sudsy or your jacket is particularly large. For best results, use a fragrance-free detergent that is specifically made for synthetic fabrics or sporting gear.

steps.headline: Soak your jacket in the soapy water for about 1 hour.
steps.description: Place your jacket in the soapy water and submerge it so it’s completely wet. Leave it to soak for about an hour to allow the detergent time to break down any stains and dirt.

steps.headline: Rinse the jacket with clean water to remove the detergent.
steps.description: First, drain the soapy water out of the sink. Then, turn the water on cold and hold the jacket under the running water. You may need to rinse the jacket several times to get all the soap suds out of the fabric. Once the soap is rinsed out, squeeze out as much water as you can without wringing it, as this can cause the insulation to clump. Air drying your jacket allows moisture to stay trapped in the insulation, which can cause it to mildew. Therefore, it’s best to dry your jacket in the dryer after hand-washing it.

steps.headline: Place about 4 clean tennis balls in the dryer.
steps.description: As the washing machine gentle cycle is finishing up, place about 4 tennis balls into the dryer. Once you start the dryer, the tennis balls will bounce around and break up any clumps of insulation that start to form.

steps.headline: Transfer the jacket to the dryer and set it on low heat.
steps.description: Place the jacket in the dryer bin on top of the tennis balls. Then, set the dryer to the lowest heat setting. Using medium or high heat can damage the synthetic materials.

steps.headline: Tumble dry the jacket, checking the dryer every 20 minutes.
steps.description: Press the start button to start the low heat dryer cycle. Then, open the dryer to check on the jacket every 20 minutes to make sure it’s not overheating. Repeat this process until the jacket is completely dry. Make sure that the jacket is completely dry before you remove it from the dryer, as any lingering moisture can cause the insulation to mold and smell.

You may need to add more detergent if the water isn’t getting sudsy or your jacket is particularly large. Place your jacket in the soapy water and submerge it so it’s completely wet. Leave it to soak for about an hour to allow the detergent time to break down any stains and dirt. Drying Your Synthetic Insulated Jacket Place about 4 clean tennis balls in the dryer. As the washing machine gentle cycle is finishing up, place about 4 tennis balls into the dryer. Once you start the dryer, the tennis balls will bounce around and break up any clumps of insulation that start to form. Transfer the jacket to the dryer and set it on low heat. Place the jacket in the dryer bin on top of the tennis balls. Then, set the dryer to the lowest heat setting. Using medium or high heat can damage the synthetic materials. Tumble dry the jacket, checking the dryer every 20 minutes. Press the start button to start the low heat dryer cycle. Then, open the dryer to check on the jacket every 20 minutes to make sure it’s not overheating. Repeat this process until the jacket is completely dry. Make sure that the jacket is completely dry before you remove it from the dryer, as any lingering moisture can cause the insulation to mold and smell.
